page.title: 02ECOLOGY AND NATURAL HISTORY
page.content: ECOLOGY, NATURAL HISTORY, CLIMATE The area is typical of Exmoor the land being very boggy with peat based soil. The grassland is very poor and is only suitable for supporting sheep. The predominant plants are bracken, gorse and heather. The underlying rock is a type of stone peculiar to the area and is known as Hangman Grits. This is a very hard form of gritstone which withstands weathering. Most of the area is over 1000 feet above sea level. The wind strength is often strong to gale force. The annual rainfall is high and the highest point of Holdstone Down is often obscured by low cloud or fog. Conversely, in time of drought, it is necessary to carry water to the sheep as there is no water supply.
